title: Dad of woman who sent chilling texts 'from inside Essex lorry' tells of heartache
text:

A mum and dad have spoken of their heartbreak after their daughter's attempt to start a better life for herself in the UK seemingly ended in tragedy.

In the wake of the horrific discovery of 39 dead bodies in the back of a lorry in an industrial estate in Grays, Essex, work has begun to identify those who tragically lost their lives.

Yesterday it was reported Vietnamese 26-year-old Pham Thi Tra had sent a harrowing text to her mum saying she couldn't breath and that her journey to the UK had not worked out as planned.

She wrote: “I’m sorry Mum. My journey abroad hasn’t succeeded. Mum, I love you so much! I’m dying because I can’t breathe ... I’m from Nghen, Can Loc, Ha Tinh, Vietnam ... I am sorry, Mum.”

(Image: CNN)

Now her parents Nguyen Thi Phong and Pham Van Thin have spoken of their heartbreak from their home in Vietnam's Ha Tinh province.

"I've lost both my loved one and my money," dad Pham said in an interview with CCN.

Despite earning the equivalent of $400 (£311) a month between them, the couple scarped together the thousands of dollars needed to send their daughter to the UK.

After they paid the smugglers, Tra My travelled through China and France on her way to Pursfleet.

(Image: CNN)

"The smugglers said that this was a ... safe route, that people would go by airplane, car ... if I had known she would go by this route, I would not have let her go," Pham said.

The devastated mum and dad are now waiting on the British and Vietnamese authorities to send their daughter's body home.

As they do the Vietnamese community in the UK is collecting photos and information about known missing persons in the hopes of identifying those currently being held at Broomfield hospital's morgue.

"We now have photos of nearly 20 people reporting missing, aged 15-45," read a statement on Viethome, a website for the Vietnamese community in the UK.

"What VietHome wants to do is help families find missing people or identify the victims accurately.

(Image: CNN)

"If anyone can come to the point of contact with VietHome, if not then we have to find another way will take more time."

If the missing people reported to VietHome prove to be among those who lost their lives on the lorry, then the youngest victim will be significantly younger than first feared.

An early police report that there was one teenager among the dead was later revised to say one young adult was in their number.

VietHome has handed the photos to the police and has asked families not to post them online.

(Image: PA)

At the beginning of the investigation Essex Police reported that the victims were Chinese nationals.

The force has since said their country of origin is a "developing picture".

As identification work continues so to does the effort to track down the people smugglers responsible for organising their transit.

So far four people have been arrested in connection with the tragedy.

Shortly after he called paramedics to the scene at 1.40am on Wednesday, officers arrested 25-year-old Mo Robinson on suspicion of murder.

The Northern Irish man remains in custody after local courts granted Essex Police permission to continue questioning him for a second time yesterday.

On Friday afternoon a 38-year-old man and woman of the same age from Warrington in Cheshire were held on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and 39 counts of manslaughter.

It is thought they are Joanna and Thomas Maher, a husband and wife who told MailOnline they previously owned the Scania lorry but sold it to a company in Ireland a year ago.

Yesterday evening a 48-year-old man from Northern Ireland was arrested at Stansted Airport on the same charges as the couple.

(Image: PA)

(Image: Peter Powell)

Police are now searching for a second lorry driver after he was filmed 10 times at a Belgium port.

CCTV cameras at Zeebrugge captured the HGV as it went through the terminal on its way to Pursfleet and then Grays in Essex.

Dutch language newspaper Het Nieuwsblad has quoted a source thought to be a Belgium official who suggested authorities on the continent are now searching for the lorry's driver before it crossed the Channel.

"We hope to catch him soon," they are quoting as saying.

"His truck was filmed 10 times at the port site."
description: The parents of Pham Thi Tra have spoken of their heartbreak after she went missing while on her way to the UK
